title: Francisco de Peñalosa
text:
Francisco de Peñalosa (c. 1470 – April 1, 1528) was a Spanish composer of the middle <a href="Renaissance%20music">Renaissance</a>.
Life.
He was born in <a href="Talavera%20de%20la%20Reina">Talavera de la Reina</a> in the province of <a href="Toledo%20%28province%29">Toledo</a>. He spent most of his career in <a href="Seville">Seville</a>, serving as the "maestro di capilla", though he also spent time in <a href="Burgos">Burgos</a>, and three years in <a href="Rome">Rome</a> at the papal chapel (1518–1521). He died in Seville.
Music and influence.
Peñalosa was one of the most famous Spanish composers of the generation before <a href="Crist%C3%B3bal%20de%20Morales">Cristóbal de Morales</a>, and his compositions were highly regarded at the time. Unfortunately for him, his music was not widely distributed; he did not benefit from the invention of <a href="printing">printing</a>, since he mostly remained in Spain, away from cities such as <a href="Venice">Venice</a> and <a href="Antwerp">Antwerp</a> which were the first centers of printed music. Later generations of Spanish composers—<a href="Francisco%20Guerrero%20%28composer%29">Guerrero</a>, Morales, <a href="Tom%C3%A1s%20Luis%20de%20Victoria">Victoria</a>—went to <a href="Italy">Italy</a> for parts of their careers, where their compositions were printed and were as widely distributed as the music of the <a href="Dutch%20School%20%28music%29">Franco-Flemish</a> composers who dominated music in Europe in the 16th century.
Peñalosa wrote <a href="mass%20%28music%29">mass</a>es, <a href="Magnificat">Magnificat</a> settings, <a href="motet">motet</a>s and <a href="hymn">hymn</a>s. Eleven secular compositions have survived, including an <a href="ensalada%20%28music%29">ensalada</a> (a form of <a href="quodlibet">quodlibet</a>) "Por las sierras de Madrid" for six voices.
Peñalosa was evidently fond of <a href="counterpoint">contrapuntal</a> puzzles and canons, as evidenced by the quodlibet, and by the Agnus Dei of his "Missa Ave Maria peregrina", which combines a <a href="plainsong">plainsong</a> tune with a <a href="Permutation%20%28music%29">retrograde</a> (backwards) version of a famous secular song by <a href="Hayne%20van%20Ghizeghem">Hayne van Ghizeghem</a>.
One of his motets ("Sancta mater istud agas") was long assumed to be by <a href="Josquin%20des%20Prez">Josquin des Prez</a>, which indicates both the stylistic similarity of their music and the high quality of Peñalosa's.
